Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Hi ladies Not been here for a while as I've been burying my head in the sand and working hard. Anyway, my onco told me I could have the portacath removed and I was delighted and went ahead. I noticed that everyone (nurse at the hospital, physiotherapist, blood test guy) all told me this was good news, but I was so desperate to be rid of it and get the scar tidied up, that I didn't give it much thought. Went to see my GP straight after it was removed and he asked if I'd had a blood test for 'markers' (not sure that's the English term?). Implications of this question hit me like a brick. (Background - surgery in April, Chemo June - August, Radio September and October. Last blood test during chemo, except for one to check I was okay for the removal procedure)  I've just had the blood test and wil get the results tomorrow, but can anyone tell me what to expect? If there are numbers, how do I interpret them? Will it just be negative (fingers crossed) or positive? I can apparently speak to a biologist at the lab, but anyone on here able to explain to me? Thanks a lot, in advance Love Lizz xxx
Posts.Title: Blood test for 'markers'

Posts.Content: Hi all, Just been to get my results (which I am happy to say are fine, according to the biologist I spoke to) so I thought I'd share what I learnt: CA125 - marker for breast cancer. Level should be below 35 U/l (mine was 12.5) CA 15-3 - ovarian cancer. Level should be below 25 U/l (me - 13.5 compared to 15.6 before lumpectomy - not sure why I had this test back in April UNLESS she misspoke when she said this marker was for ovarian cancer, and it should be the other way round?) CA19-9 - intestinal cancer (no idea why the GP ordered this) Level should be below 39U/l (me - 10.4) There is also an ACE marker which she didn't refer to but for smokers the level should be below 5.5 and for non-smokers below 3.8. (me - 1.1) On reflection, and reading what others have written here, I think perhaps these markers are not a very accurate indicator, but I still feel better for knowing that I haven't missed having a vital test, and that this one has come back okay.  Do women in the UK routinely get MRIs or bone scans after treatment? I has a scan before chemo, but now I'm on my own until my next check-up in April. Does that sound normal? Thank you all very much,  Lots of love Lizz xxx

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlesticks I have no bra recommendations, but I am only 40km from Avignon (to the west) and it's lovely round here. St Remy is gorgeous but a little bit like Hampstead! My absolutely favourite place to visit is the Pont du Gard - about 30km from Avignon. You can swim in the river, there are sunny, and a few shady, places on the riverbank / beach, as well as the magnificent aqueduct. Plenty of walking trails. It will be very hot, but I think the car park is open from quite early in the morning till midnight or perhaps later. (It closes so that people can't stay there in their camper vans). I don't feel like I'm selling it very well, but it really is absolutely wonderful.  I have my next chemo on Friday, but if you wanted to go there on Sunday, say,  I'd be happy to come an meet you (and I should be okay on day 3, fingers crossed). On Sunday morning the covered market in Avignon is fantastic - if you're self-catering you could buy some lovely treats: best to get there early. Further afield is Uzès which has a lovely Provençal market in Saturday and Wednesday. Also, you could check out les carrières de lumière www.lesbauxdeprovence.com/.../16-carrieres-de-lumieres which is near les Baux de Provence - they have an exhibition (this year it's Chagall) using video projections in an old, enormous, limestone quarry. They animate some of the paintings, and in previous years (Cézanne was my favourite) it has been brilliant. It's also lovely and cool on a hot summer's day. I realise this wasn't what you wanted, but hey, maybe it'll be of some interest. Either way, have a lovely, lovely time. Lots of love Lizz xxx

Posts.Title: oncoDX result

Posts.Content: Hi  I know some of you, (Sarah, Karen, and some names I've forgotten) are in France, and even that someone said she teaches English so I wonder if you have any experience of going into a state school wearing a scarf. I teach adults but for one particular client the classes are held in a lycée and students (adult and pre-BAC) are not allowed to wear a scarf on school premises. I have kept my cancer completely secret from my employers (maybe wrongly, but that was the choice I made) so I don't know what to do when September comes. I have lost almost all my hair (I can tease a few strands out around the edges of a scarf or hat) and seem to be getting on reasonably well with scarves. I ordered a wig but it didn't suit me at all. I'm waiting for a second one to arrive, but I realised that one of the main reasons I was even considering a wig was for this particular work situation. I know I can (probably should) confide in my principal contact person, but even with her 'permission' (and the idea I'd need permission is galling) I can't prevent a disgruntled student challenging me. I had a student last year who tried to get away with wearing a scarf and was taken aside and rebuked - she is the kind of person I can well imagine not taking kindly to the teacher getting special privileges. I realise I could probably avoid some of the hassle by just being open, but instinctively since my diagnosis I have not wanted people to know because I imagine they will treat me differently. Any ideas or experience? Thanks  Love Lizz xxx

Posts.Content: Hi ladies Thank you for your reassurance - I feel better now - I think it was a middle-of-the-night panic mainly.  I envy you in the UK who can get R1R2 on prescription - if I order it here it'll cost about 100€ for a six week course, and I am reluctant to spend that much (although, I probably need to give myself a good talking to about priorities - what exactly am I saving my money for?) It seems complicated if you have to keep your breast uncovered for 20 minutes after you apply the gel because I am usually going straight back to work, so I'm probably not an ideal candidate for that, anyway. Karen, thank you. especially for replying from your holiday retreat. I have a friend (a nurse) whose husband is a doctor and I've asked him if he might be able to prescribe the 100% hyaluronic acid cream. He is heavily into homeopathy and has already given me a very detailed prescription of various granules (mostly reimbursed) and essential oils (not), but I hope he's not opposed to this cream - I just discovered that the one my oncologist gave me contains parabens which is extremely frustrating when I've tried to eliminate them from every other product since before chemo. You're right that things seem very different from one French region to another. I am disappointed that I didn't have a different onco for chemo - the brusque one has been the one I've been under throughout although he is a radio specialist. On a positive note, as the Cancer Centre only opened last autumn I imagine all the machines are brand spanking state-of-the-art new. And the technicians are certainly lovely. I'm just really scared of what I don't know or can't prepare for, I suppose. After the first chemo I felt a lot more confident going into the second, but I'm frightened that the radio side effects creep up on you. Thank goodness for this site and all you lovely women. I'll try to sleep tonight, and not wake up and post another panic. Lots of love and thanks Lizz xxx
Posts.Title: Minimising radiotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: Hi I've just started radio and my oncologist (who is brusque, talks really quickly and doesn't allow opportunity to engage) said something I didn't really follow yesterday. He was referring to my lumpectomy scar and how it will 'change' during radio. Having been told to keep it protected from the sun for the first six months to give it the best chance to fade, am I now going to have it darken and become more visible anyway? Can I do anything to prevent that happening? (obviously not in the five hours before treatment - everyone's made that REALLY clear!) I dreaded chemo but actually knowing the side effects were temporary made it a bit more bearable (although I am not coping well with having no hair) - suddenly being thrust into radio and hearing about irreversible side effects is really frightening me. Can I do anything to minimise them?  (Hardening and shrinking of the breast have also been mentioned, and it was only tiny before the WLE!) I have heard about a great cream (R2D2? I think not, but similar in name ) I didn't want to spend any more money but suddenly I can't sleep for worrying so if this is a wonder product perhaps I'll have to. I so didn't expect radio to frighten me, but I haven't slept more than 3 hours a night since Saturday and the real sessions only started yesterday along with back-to-school so I'm already a frazzled wreck and it's only Wednesday morning, Help, please. Thanks Love Lizz xxx
Posts.Title: Minimising radiotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: Hi ladies I'm sorry I haven't been back to thank all of you who have posted (especially Helen Snowy's mum for the great tit shots!). I am sometimes slow to respond on here but I always read the replies and often look at new posts - I'm probably not alone in finding it difficult sometimes to talk about what I'm going through, and so I avoid answering, but I always appreciate the messages I read. This community is a fantastic resource and I really value being able to come on here to panic, or moan or occasionally to offer support to others.  I have calmed down a bit now, but I also took Karen's (lacomtekp's) advice and asked a doctor friend (my own doctors are hard to approach) to give me a prescription for hyaluronic acid. Posts.Title: PICC Line - yes or no?

Posts.Content: Hi,  I'd just like to start a personal crusade about the term cold cap. I am in France, so apologies if there is no confusion in the U.K. , but I fought for the 'cold cap' and what I was given at my first session of chemo was a shower cap with the type of cooling pouches that physiotherapists use. It was obviously inadequate and I spent the rest of the day in floods of tears. However, my distress led me to contact Paxman who manufacture and supply a scalp-cooling system. It is now widespread in the U.K. (and I have got one into my chemo centre for a 3 month trial, and the nurses are all fully behind it) so I am trying to start a one-person campaign to refer to 'scalp-cooling' if it's a proper refrigerated system = effective, and to avoid 'cold-capping' = imprecise terminology - ask more questions. Lynnwad who posts here has had a great success with Paxman, as I think have other posters. It is brilliant. Oh, and I fought tooth and nail against chemo until my Oncotype DX result indicated that it would bring real benefits, and then I gave in, and apart from the hugely disappointing cold cap experience it has been okay. There are side effects, mostly manageable, and remarkably it does go quite quickly (I'm halfway through 4 cycles of TC and then will have 33 sessions of radiotherapy). Personally I was at my worst between surgery in mid-April and chemo starting mid-June - it was the fear and uncertainty, I think.  All the very best Love Lizz
Posts.Title: Question re Breast Cancer chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Just jumping in to say that I may (fingers crossed, and not wanting to tempt fate) be one of the people for whom T come without too many negative reactions. Yes, I've had side effects (hair loss being the one I have talked about most on here, but actually avoidable for many who have access to a proper scalp cooling system, and of course, for those who choose the extra inconvenience and discomfort). I have now completed two cycles (of four x TC) and first cycle I had mammoth mouth ulcers, but I felt them developing during dinner one night, so could perhaps have avoided them if I'd eaten softer or less spicy foods, and a nasty rash probably caused by the sun through the car window (I've always had sensitive skin, and it's the first thing to flare up when I'm stressed). In both cycles I was very tired for about a week, but this lifted (more slowly in cycle 2), and, honestly, apart from a very itchy/spotty scalp, and an outbreak of acne (hormone related, I suppose) as well as what I take to be hot flushes (but we've also had temperatures in the 30s and at night it didn't drop below 20 for a week, so it could just be that) I have been FINE In fact, my partner, who is, imo, a hypochondriac, has complained about her health much more than I have about mine, (ever since diagnosis, tbh!) and except when I have left handfuls of hair in the bathroom bin, or been falling-down tired, has completely ignored the fact that I'm going through chemo! (This is not ideal, for any partners reading this - I am never ill, so it would have been lovely to have been slightly pampered during this period, and excused my fair share of cooking, cleaning and washing-up.) Anyway, I hope I haven't spoken too soon, and thanks, Karen, for starting this thread - I hope lots of people who are worried before they start T will be reassured. Lots of love, Lizz  xxxx
Posts.Title: Taxotere.........please stop panicking!

Posts.Content: Hi ladies Just jumping in to say how much I agree with you all, and the articulacy with which you have expressed yourselves. At my first chemo session the cold cap was offered very reluctantly and was inadequate (to say the least) so I'm on tenterhooks now (day 16) waiting to see how much hair will drop out. (So far not too much, although it seems to have accelerated a bit yesterday and today - perhaps because I'm being more active in week 3!) I was so upset after the first session that my girlfriend offered to shave her hair - talk about not getting it! It made me feel that on top of the fear and trauma of losing my hair, I had no one to talk to who could begin to understand. On a VERY POSITIVE note, I also got in touch with Paxman (I actually left a sobbing voicemail when I got home from the first session, before sending a calmer but still plaintive e-mail) who acted very promptly and have arranged a trial of one of their systems at the cancer centre (in France) where I'm being treated, and I'm going in to act as an interpreter for the training day tomorrow. So a really big thanks to them, and best wishes to you all. Love Lizz xxx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi all I just had this from Channel 4 - It seems it's a pro forma reply as I specifically did not complain. I am posting my original comment, too, so you can see that they did not really address it. I'd be interested to know if anyone is approached to give a counterpoint.  "I have just heard (so this is not a complaint but only a comment) that Stephen Merchant shaved his head as part of the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign, and that everyone in the studio had a great laugh about it. Please could you consider doing a rebuttal piece from someone who has lost his/her hair through chemotherapy. I am one of those (currently I have around 1cm of regrowth after my hair fell out around the end of June) and losing my hair was one of the most traumatic things about having cancer. Seeing a shiny scalp in the mirror for weeks, losing eyebrows, eyelashes and pubic hair not for a couple of days until stubble reappeared but for months, has not been fun or remotely funny. I was often overwhelmed by sadness or frustration that I couldn't just walk out of the front door (or even look out of the window onto a busy street) without first putting on a hat or scarf. I was not comfortable without a scarf on even at home, and bought a wig to wear when I went back to work. Psychologically working has done wonders for me, but I hate the wig, which is itchy and restricts my movement (try looking up when something you are wearing around your head is only held on by elastic), and I daren't take a top off over my head in public in case the wig comes too, so as summer changed to autumn and cold mornings developed into warm days I had to suffer being too hot or cold until I could find a private place with a mirror to sort myself out. I am not alone in having hated losing my hair, so please do a piece about other ways of showing support or of the effect of hair loss on those who have had no choice. It is not vanity - I did not want people to know I had cancer - I wanted to be treated the same way as usual, and that included not losing clients because they think that illness = unreliability. People have in fact been very complimentary about my 'new hairstyle', i.e. the wig, but that does not make the horror of hair loss disappear. Alopecia is not the same as a shaved head. Please give this side of the story. Thank you." Thank you for contacting Channel 4 Viewer Enquiries regarding SUNDAY BRUNCH. We are sorry to hear that you were unhappy with comments made by Stephen Merchant during this programme, which you found offensive. Please be advised that Stephen Merchant in no way meant to belittle people that had lost their hair through undergoing chemotherapy when making these comments. We would like to apologise for any offense that these comments caused. Nevertheless, please be assured your concerns have been logged and noted for the information of those responsible for our programming. Thank you again for taking the time to contact us. We appreciate all feedback from our viewers; complimentary or otherwise.   Regards,    Scarlet Lewis Channel 4 Viewer Enquiries Love Lizz xxx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I don't watch Sunday Brunch but I feel strongly that this campaign misses the point spectacularly so I have sent a comment to Channel 4 (couldn't complain when I hadn't seen it) explaining that shaving does not have the same effect as alopecia (whether through chemo or another cause). I mentioned the months of a shiny scalp, the lack of eyebrows and eyelashes, and pubic hair and the need I felt to hide my baldness because I wanted to hide my cancer - I did not want to advertise that I was sick, when frankly I didn't feel ill (except through the side effects of chemo). I also referred to the deep sadness that could well up at any time, but most often for me when I saw myself in the mirror. I suggested they invite someone to give the counter arguments. I hope they will take notice of us. Perhaps this will become the public forum that we have been searching for, for a discussion about the campaign. I now have about 1cm of soft, more-grey-than-I'd-like regrowth - last chemo was on 12th August. My wig, on the other hand is luxuriant. Looking forward to needing a haircut and being able to have a colour. Not sure when I'll go 'commando' - maybe after Christmas?  Love to all Lizz x
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi Ann, I think I gave my thread a misleading title. (Is it possible to change it?) I actually want to start a campaign to use distinct terminology so that women know what they're being offered. This is perhaps the first time it's come up as a semantic issue, but I'd like to suggest that we try to use scalp-cooling for the systems which circulate a cool liquid throughout treatment (and before and after, obviously) and relegate cold cap to the basic technique where a cap is changed regularly but not kept at a constant low temperature. I am also asking Paxman for their input, I really do feel strongly about this issue. But I am just about to hit TC day four and will probably have no energy left tomorrow or for the next week to fight this particular battle. Anyone wanna join my army or even understand what the hell I'm on about ? Love Lizz xxx
Posts.Title: Difference between 'cold cap' and 'scalp-cooling'

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn.  I might be trying to reinvent the wheel, but my idea is that we start using e.g. Scalp-cooling to refer to a system that doesn't rely on frozen water, but is based on a circulating liquid which keeps the head at a constant low temperature. I have asked Paxman for their input, but don't have an answer yet. My ignorance sprang from the generic term being imprecise. I know I'm being dogmatic, but we take a lot of trouble to distinguish between FEC and T or between triple negative, O+ Pr+ Her2+, etc, and slowly we learn about our disease and treatment. I'd like to add this level of clarity to our discussion of hair-loss prevention.  I'm probably banging my head against a brick wall, which will hurt even more with so little hair  ! I wonder if I'll regret setting this hare running? (No pun intended) Love as always Lizz xxxxx
Posts.Title: Difference between 'cold cap' and 'scalp-cooling'

I may start a campaign or another thread when I've got a bit more energy.  Paxman do use 'scalp-cooling' so I think it may be the opposite way to your post, btw. Love very weary Lizz xxx
Posts.Title: Difference between 'cold cap' and 'scalp-cooling'

Posts.Content: Hi, I am halfway through 4 cycles of TC chemo and I wondered if I could get your experiences of 'cold-capping'. Specifically what you understand by the term and whether you know now, or knew before you started chemo that scalp-cooling is not the same. (Actually, perhaps you can confirm that I've got that right - I'm in France and may have fallen down a linguistic rabbit hole, but I don't think I have). With apologies to all those who've heard this story too many times already, I fought for a cold cap, although the chemo nurse was opposed because it wouldn't work. When I saw what they provided, (a shower cap with the type of ice packs used by physiotherapists) I realised that it wasn't going to work. My distress propelled me to contact a company I'd come across when I was looking for info and they (Paxman - perhaps other scalp-cooling systems exist, but this is the only one I know) got a trial set up in my chemo unit within a fortnight. I have now used this system twice although my hair loss after cycle one was already pretty catastrophic, and it is brilliant. I'd like to bring some clarity to this issue, simply by asking if you were aware of the difference and whether you would support the idea of using different descriptions for these two very different approaches. We already specify what tumour we had, the chemo we are having, etc. because it make a big difference, and so I think it makes sense to convey the important difference between these two approaches to preventing or slowing hair loss.  So, a one-woman crusade (perhaps because I teach English, I am a bit obsessed about the accurate use of language  ) to help those who come after us lobby for something that could be really effective.  If the shower cap affair no longer exists in the UK I apologise for wasting your time. With love Lizz
Posts.Title: Difference between 'cold cap' and 'scalp-cooling'

Posts.Content: I think I failed to express myself clearly (ironic given my proposition!). I want to encourage us to use more accurate language because if cool cap refers to everything how can we be sure we're getting the one that'll work. The 'contraption' is excellent while the Heath Robinson shower cap affair is pointless (imo). My wish is that no one else will be given the false hope I had, simply by using a more targeted term. We all take loads of time to read and respond to other posters questions about treatment protocols, so we are good at learning a new language - can we make a concerted effort to use a term which reflects the actual system used. If I had known that a cold cap could be so useless I might have acted sooner to get a scalp-cooling trial in my local unit - I 'suffered' through ignorance (yes, I know it's nothing in the scheme of cancer treatment) and that could have been avoided.  So a plea to join me in a search for clarity of expression. Climbing off soapbox now. Love Lizz xxx

Posts.Title: Thinking of turning down chemo

Posts.Content: mistymoley Hi Lizz Our instincts are an amazing resource, we need to be able to listen to ourselves and take note.  When you get the results of the Oncotype DX test, be very aware of your reaction.  If it's a no to chemo, you will feel relief and be able to move on.  If it's a yes, listen VERY carefully.  Do you go into blind panic?  Does it make you more determined NOT to have it, or do you start to accept that it's for the best.  As you said yourself, only you can make this decision.  As long as you are happy with it, then that is the main thing.   I know you are slightly older than some of us, so this can be a factor, as well as any other health problems that may be exacerbated by the chemo.   I wish you luck and peace with your decision. Your reference to my being slightly older was the first thing that has made me feel like me! The surgeon and oncologist keep going on about my young age and bizarrely I was upset (not very!) when you stated the bleedin' obvious - I'm NOT young anymore. (how young are you, btw?) The pre-cancer me is jealous, but considering how badly I'm handling it at 53 (firmly in denial) , I'd never have coped in my 30s or 40s. Love, and thanks for the reminder of the old me! Love Lizz x
